text: Good morning everyone.
Today is February 3RD, 2020.
The Council briefing of Seattle city council WELCOMES to order.
It is 9:32.
I am Teresa Mosqueda, pro Tem president for today.
I am joined by my Council callings, Councilmember Sawant, one and her Lewis, Councilmember Pedersen, and Councilmember Mosqueda.
I have not yet been here for Council briefing so I haven't been able to rattle that off the tongue but it's great to see you all.
This is my first day after maternity leave or parental leave.

I want to say a huge thank you to my staff who have been holding down the Fort, and working with all of you in the 2020 session of the previous Council and weight of the budget and transactions prior to budget.
A huge amount of appreciation for them.
Welcome to 2020, and I look forward to working with all of you guys.
I am sorry I wasn't able to be at many of you getting swearing in.
Councilmember Pedersen, I will remember this from now on.
I am on the hook.
Before we get started with updates from each of the Councilmembers, we have the office of Intergovernmental relations.
We would love to have you introduce yourselves and give us an update for the Council agenda for the 2020 session.
Before we do that, I would like to approve the minutes we have.
I'd like to make a motion to approve the minutes.
Second.
Any other comments.
Moved and Seconded.
All in favor?
Aye.
Great.
The Mets have been approved.
Let's have you introduce yourself and do an overview of the 2020 session.
Thank you.
Lily Wilson-Codega, director of the office of Intergovernmental relations.
Robin Koskey, office of Intergovernmental relations.
Quinn Majeski, government relations at Sdot, --
And Cheryl SWAB, director of Oir.
We are heading into the fourth week of the short 60 day legislated session scheduled to an promotional.

We are quickly approaching the House of policy origin cut off on February 7. I know many of you are aware of activity around progressive revenue with the introduction of MCRAE's proposal hospital 2907.
Allowing King County to impose an excise tax on large employers to fund housing and homelessness support services.
The bill is expected to generate around $121 million a year and will be heard in-house finances Tuesday at 8:00 A.M.
We saw the death penalty bill passed the Senate 28-18.
And automated enforcement passed the House 50-40 on the 30th, which Quinn will cover in more detail.
We will review the transportation section later on today.
I will turn it to Cheryl, beginning with the education section on the top of page 1.
I'm just going to do a quick overview of the bills I talked about last week, and at a couple of things to that.

On the comprehensive Consensual ball, the house is scheduled for executive action, and the bill that would require schools to provide free Menstrual products for Stuents, has not yet been scheduled for executive action.
Quickly, I wanted to mention two early learning bills.
The fair start for contract, in the early care for education act.
Both have been passed out of respective committees.
Both bills propose large-scale expansions to Childcare, preschool, family support systems, dual language learning, and workforce development.
The hospital has been identified as the vehicle for legislation this session while the Senate bill is intended as a roadmap for long-term early learning investments.
Neither bill identifies a funding source for these expansions yet, but a proposed funding source for the hospital is anticipated later in the session.
Thank you.
Moving on to the environment.
Quinn?
A few updates in the environmental arena.
First, low carbon fuel standard, which requires transportation fuels to reduce the carbon intensity by 20% by 2022 and 20% by 2025, passed the House 52-44 .% that was on January 30.
There were no amendments.
It is expected to have some challenge in the Senate, but we are continuing to press forward on that.
One new bill that I do want to flag, the title is just greenhouse gas emissions.
But it's known as the authority build out on Olympia.

This piece of legislation unfolds to the January 16 Washington Supreme Court decision, which ruled that the Department of Ecology Overstepped its regulatory authority in regulating indirect, or mobile sources of emissions.
This legislation would essentially restore that statutory authority, so they can continue those regulations following that ruling.
This is an emerging priority for the environmental community, and one that we expect may actually have some momentum, so continuing to work closely on that.
And then Finally, I want to flag the heating oil insurance.
We have some concerns about that.
On the House side, it did include some language we were looking for around providing the Department of are the pollution liability agency with the ability to support low income homeowners.
The Senate didn't, so we are going to continue working on that to make sure that thing which is included.
Thank you.
Moving to general government on the bottom of page 2.
The Digital equity bill, had executive action taken in the house on January 31.
It looks like it will be moving.
The facial recognition bill was introduced on January 27.
We had a hearing on January 31.
It's scheduled for executive action on February 4.

Anticipated privacy date of legislation continues to see movement this session, passed out of its policy committee and is my physical committee with a January 30 public hearing for ways and means, not scheduled for executive action.
The companion bill is scheduled for executive action on February 5.
Moving on to Healthcare, Robin?
The governor's request for legislation around Vaping is moving forward.
This bill expands on increasing needs to purchase of Vaping products to 21.
It bands flavored Vaping products, and ones with vitamin E acetate in them.
It limits nicotine, and requires manufacturers and distributors to list them for the Department of health.
This is scheduled for executive session this afternoon at 1:30.
I don't think the hospital has been scheduled for any executive action yet.
I also just wanted to highlight a couple other bills that are not on your sheet, that our contract lobbyist in Olympia pointed out to us.
One is by representative Mccreary, hospital 1967 offering extended health coverage from Undocumented young adults.
It is meant to make sure that people with--variable to access insurance between the ages of 19 and 26 if they have Undocumented status, so they Úwould still be able to get medical coverage.
Pause real quick on that one.
It's always sad when we hear about bills we worked on 10 years ago still in the mix.
This is one I worked on about five years ago, so you've mentioned it's not on our list.
I assume it is now.
It is now, yes.
It's just not--I mean, we are tracking it.
It's just not part of the Council briefing.
But you signed pro for our legislative agenda.
Absolutely.
Okay.
There's also a bill on dental therapy, which is health bill 1370 authorizing a dental therapist to practice statewide.
It would basically just expand coverage around the state.
This has also been a multiyear effort, so we are hoping it does get some Traction this year, and actually pass.
If I may, there is one more bill on health care.
I am trying to find the number for you.
It relates to making sure that individuals can have access to Healthcare after they deliver a child.
I believe there is a two-month window where individuals are allowed to keep their health coverage, and if they then do not have Healthcare, they are not eligible to keep it.
I am trying to find it.
This would allow individuals to keep their health coverage for at least up to a year Postpartum.
I believe our contract lobbyists are tracking that one.
I will make sure we put this on the list, as well.
I will move on to housing and homelessness.
Today is housing and homelessness advocacy day.
Councilmember Mireles is wearing a pin.
I'm sure it's usually 600 to 700 people who show up in Olympia to advocate for bills that support housing and homelessness.
I will be heading down there.
I know there is also office of housing staff advocating for Olympia, and people generally from around the state will be there, so it's very exciting.
The governor had a significant proposal to expand the aged, blind, and disabled program.

That was taken out of the rainy day Fund, which I think everyone is sort of an agreement that there won't be the momentum to get the votes, to use the money from the rainy day Fund, but the Washington housing alliance also has a budget proposal around trying to make sure there is a little bit of expansion to those two programs, and I think there's a possibility there may be action on that.
I wanted to let you know, we are watching that as a budget item.
There are several bills, so many housing bills it's sort of unbelievable.
It certainly points to what a priority this is for legislators because even in the short session, you see this spends almost 3 pages in your update.
I will go through the bill white bill.

We will certainly offer to follow up with you if you have questions on particular bells, but there are three bills that I think we have most of the authority to do in Seattle, which are just cause Eviction, and then the house and justice act bill that would prohibit landlords from using criminal records that Senator Daniel is supporting in the Senate, Senate bill 6490.
There's also an installment payment bill, the first bill on your list, hospital 1694.
Those are all moving forward, and still very active in Olympia.
Councilmember Sawant?
Thank you.
I am not sure if I missed you talking about 2907.
If I might ask you some questions about that.
Sure.
Can you go over the outlines of this bill very quickly?
I know it authorizes counties with populations over 2,000,002 past taxes, but specifically, what I would like to hear from you right now is, what was the conversation like when this was put forward?
I wasn't here last Monday because I was out of town, but if you did do a briefing or did Oir do a brief?
Was this mentioned at that time or not?
As far as my office is concerned, we only heard it in the press.
I am really concerned if this is not brought to the Council in the briefings, the first chance that you got, so if you could explain that.
Also, in terms of the outlines of this, and what's been announced by the county, this bill does not make the taxes happen.
It just gives the authority to the county to do the tax.

If the county were to pass the tax, from what I've understood, if this state though passes the county would effectively erase $40 million for Seattle, which I think is pitiful given the scale of the crisis.
I would like you to talk about the discussion from elected officials at the county and state level, and also with the Mayor things.
Just to make it very clear, this is even less than the bill that was passed, and repealed by the majority of the Council in 2018.
Councilmember Mosqueda and I voted against the bill.
To me, that's extremely concerning when even the McKinsey report, which is not a Socialist report.
It's a report from the Chamber, and big businesses.
Even they are very frankly saying, the crisis is so bad, that it would require raising anywhere from $400 Million- $1 billion every year.
That's how bad the crisis is.
It seems like this is Tom deaf to the crisis.
And then the other question is, what's the conversation on any State ban?
I imagine big businesses are only including that.
I am going to go ahead and start.
As you know, this is part of a broad conversation, and in the beginning, the legislation had not been introduced since our last briefing.
It has something been introduced, which is why we are briefing you on it today.
We will keep you updated as things develop.
At this stage, there is no Preemption in the legislation.

That's something, given the councils Prioritization of Progressive revenue, a conversation we definitely want to be at the stable table for Carm stay engaged in, the amount that the proposal would raise is $120 million as the estimate currently.
I will have Robin fill in the Perimeters, but we hear your concerns and understand that very clearly.
We will continue to keep everyone updated as this proposal moves forward through the legislative process.

I would just add that it's a payroll tax on earners that about $150,000 per year, and the focus of what the revenue would be used for is housing, homelessness, behavioral health, and public safety, but the public safety portion isn't meant for law enforcement.
It's from the services, so people engaged with the public safety system could have access to services.
I think Councilmember Sawant's points are well taken.
I am also sorry I was not able to have a conversation prior to this bill being introduced, as well, but I do have a lot of trust in representative Mccreary.
I know she's heard concerns lot unclear foam Pucks calling for additional housing, and I know she is well aware that $100 million or $120 million is not sufficient.
$40 million coming to the city of Seattle would be a drop in the bucket.

We were looking at $48 million with the scaled down version of the hours tax, so I appreciate the skill Councilmember Sawant has Oakland, and I I started to understand we need to look at partnership with are County cities with Governance and King County.
In doing so, we would want to make sure we can layer any additional services we would need, and that we also are not only looking at shelter services.
I think everyone has talked about requiring an investment in housing long-term.
I think I appreciate other item Agendas looking at tenant protection and Scaling up housing.
I want to underscore the point around Preemption.
Having any bills that takes away tools on the cusp of a recession would be problematic.
As the now chair of finance and budget, I believe we have a serious conversation we need to uphold about how we can allow for cities to have tools in their Toolkit.
We may need dollars at some point to raise for apprenticeship programs or Childcare programs, or small business support.
When we have tools in our Toolkit, that doesn't mean they are up for grabs when there's another proposal on the table.
We do appreciate County folks wanting to potentially step in, but there is a lot of unknown manner.

As you continue your conversation in Olympia, thank you for recognizing that the city, in my perspective, I will speak for myself, that city Councilmembers as the legislative branch, this is a legislative tool we have that we would need to continue to be updated about in the conversation because a conversation about for moving this tool seems very dangerous, especially when we are responsible for a very complex budget with a potential recession on the horizon.
The concept of giving away a tool at the city level is something we have fought year after year.
Our friends at the Awc fight Preemption all the time.
Having a conversation at a syllable tool requires a city council discussion.
I want to underscore your points.
I think they are well taken and an important part of the dialogue in Olympia.
Councilmember Sawant.
Thank you.
I really appreciate you sort of joining in that point about how we want County tax and city tools.
It should be a statement that that's how Seattle got into this.

Seattle has the most Regressive tax mission because the state has translated our ability to raise progressive revenues, and so any talk towards a state ban or passing big business taxes, Preemption, the reason I'm saying state that, Preemption is not clear to a lot of people who are not engaged deeply into city and state politics.
I think that would go in the wrong direction.
I would be curious if you can report any public statements made by progressive Democrats about holding the line on the state that.
And I would also like to note that the reason this is happening has to do with how much momentum there is among the public to actually address this problem.
I agree that the balance of solutions has to be toward providing housing and strengthening tenant rights because prevention is the best solution really to end homelessness.
Thank you.
Just to respond, in terms of the press from elected officials, we are happy to aggregate any of the news that we have access to, and send out your way.
I think there have been a lot of generalities at this point, in terms of legislators saying, we are beginning this conversation.
But just to underscore why I'm focusing on this, is that instinctively, you would be Nace and politics do not know that this is the real price and big business wants out of this.
They have fought tooth and nail any taxes on them, and the only reason they would agree to something like this is if they can get the real price, which is a ban on cities doing it.
Basically, Seattle doing this.
The reason I'm focusing on this is because publicly, the downtown Seattle Association has already issued a letter in which they are making it really clear what they want from this, is exactly this.
Cities like Seattle not being able to pass their own taxes.
Thank you.
Councilmembers any other questions?
Councilmember Pedersen.
Interested in hearing more about the exemptions for small businesses you mentioned.

I believe there will be some small business support at the hearing on Tuesday something businesses under 50 employees, and I believe is embraced by the small business community but I should retract that until I get confirmation.
Others on my team have more information.
Councilmember Lewis.
This is more of a procedural question about potential advocacy for the bill or what the city's official position is at this point.
Speaking purely for myself at this point, the bill in its current form is something I very enthusiastically support.
It's a progressive tax assessed on a Countywide basis.
It currently doesn't have a Preemption.
It's definitely something we can build on.
It's something I would like to see enacted and implemented.
My position and opinion on this bill could certainly evolve throughout the give and take of the legislative session.

I guess my question is, whether we are currently in a position where the city's posture is advocate to maintain the bill in its current form, and how the office will work to represent the Council and the executive to convey potential differing opinions.
Based on how it does evolve in Olympia, just flagging that now.
Since this is a short session, we might not have that many additional briefings between now and significant movement on this bill.
I haven't really canvassed my colleagues to see what all of us are generally thinking, but that's my first question, more procedural.
I think we are strongest in Olympia priorities about progressive revenue and other priorities for the Council when we have a unified position at the city level.
That is something we will work very hard to make sure that everyone on Council, everyone's concerns are addressed.
This is something moving very quickly right now.
We will continue to keep you updated individually as we hear concerns back from you.
At this stage, I have not heard from anyone that they do not support the proposal in the current form.
Our plan is to sign pro on Tuesday.
If things change in the meantime, we are in constant communication with you all around those changes, and what the city's position will be.
We will make sure to keep everyone engaged as the process moves forward.
Let me extrapolate a little bit.
The point is well taken.
Úit does seem like you are Articulating or expressing to legislators that there is significant concern.
For a ban.
That relates to individual Councilmembers.
Is that fair?
I believe Councilmember Strauss also echoed those concerns in Olympia last week.
Councilmember Rallis?
I want to make it clear from my perspective that this bill, I think doesn't go far enough.
As Councilmember Sawant said, we know we have huge needs.
How we can layer on top of what chemists generate, $48 million, as a fraction to address our crisis in the city.
I want to make it really clear that I am a hard pass on exemption.

I think it's really important that, as a city, we have every tool available to us to address the needs in the city, particularly for the folks were most honorable and at risk of getting pushed out of the city.
That means we need to be able to raise the revenue in a progressive way to fund many, many needs we have in the city.
We will be in constant communication for sure.
Thank you for hearing these concerns, and questions.
Any other questions?
Councilmember Lewis?
I have one about a different bill, 5946.
Senator Nguyen's bill on shelters, and Encampments.
Just wondering kind of what the prospect for that bill is looking like now that we are in the center of the session.
I know it got fairly close.
Last session.
It's an important consideration in our conversations, internally about the transition ordinance we are currently considering as a Council.
It has some implications for that.
I was just wondering if anyone might have an update on how that bill is looking, and making its way through the process this year, if there's any update on it.
It did pass the Senate, which is good news.
I know it continues to be a priority for Senator Nguyen, and our Department of inspections.
It is in the house and environment committee right now.
I don't know if it has been scheduled for a hearing.
I'm guessing it might take a little while since it has already passed one house, so it's not subject to the cutoffs right now, but I can certainly keep you updated on the progress of that bill.
Thank you so much.
Absolutely.
Go ahead, director Wilson.
I was going to say, if there were no other questions, I would move on to public safety, but there are still further questions.
I opened the questions.
We do have two more hands.
Do you mind?
Absolutely.
Just general comments.
I can wait until the end.
Go ahead.
It was just to say, I had a good time in Olympia last week.
Thank you to all of your staff on your speaking points for the red light, don't block box bill.
Thank you for your help.
Absolutely.
It was a really great experience being at the Association of Washington City board.
We missed you, Councilmember Mosqueda.
I'm sure we will see you again.
In every single one of the conversations at Awc, local control was emphasized.
That was just a ringing talking point in my mind all day, so just wanted to say thank you for all of your support in Olympia.
I felt very well supported in your expertise.
Thank you.
Well said.
Thank you for being down there on behalf of the city Council, as well.
Councilmember Sawant, and then we will turn it over.
I was wondering if under the general government, we have Senator Nguyen's bill 6280 on facial recognition services.
If you could give a quick summary on what the bill is considering, and what government agencies would be under the Purview of this bill.
I will take a stab at that.
The bill actually applies to businesses rather than government agencies.
It's any business located in Washington are targeting Washington consumers.
I am doing this right, aren't I?
You just look worried.
The controls or processes personal data of 100 or more as well as more than 25,000 consumers, or derive more than 50% of revenues from the sale of personal data.
So, a similar measure passed the Senate last year before dying in the house.
The bill seeks to provide regulation, of facial recognition technology through judicial oversight, transparency measures, and community engagement.
The bills are supported by Microsoft, ACLU, and legal communities have concerns.
Just very quickly, wondering if Oir could give --
The ACLU and legal communities have concerns.
I did not mean to say they are supporting.

In relation to that, if Oir could, at some point, give us a summary of those concerns, and also, it's quite stunning to hear that there are actually all of these businesses making money off of selling it.
We kind of know that's going on, but it would be good to know what corporations we are talking about.
Like, if you can give some examples because Obviously, that is the motivation behind this bill.
We can happily compile that, and send that to your office.
Without further Ado, would you like to go through another section?
I will be brief.
I know time is short.
Just highlights of the public safety section.

We continue to see momentum around gun responsibilities, and including the governor and attorneys request to ban assault weapons, High-Capacity magazines, and effort resulting from last year's study bill to Centralize Washington's background check system, the Johansen proposal, as well as an effort to repeal the statute Preempting local jurisdictions from regular eating firearms.
We have also included an update on the felony Dui Firearm restriction bill, and Senate bill 6163 towards the bottom of page 6, which passed the Senate law last week.
And another proposal to establish the office of Firearm prevention, which I know is important to Councilmember more Rallis.
Also passed out of committee and has been referred to ways and means.
Under safety net on page 7, modeled on Councilmember Mosqueda's bill of rights.
Hospital 2511 is scheduled for House labor on Tuesday.
Senate bill 6313 the top of eight would allow 17-Year-Olds the ability to vote in the primary if they will turn 18 by the general election.
I'm excited about that.
And one we have not listed in your report today, but we will include next week, that we wanted to highlight, Senate bill 6228.

It would restore voting rights to those with felony Conictions serving out their community custody, and unless there are any questions, I will turn it over to Quinn, who will cover transportation on page 8.
I have one comment on the domestic workers bill.
Thank you for underscoring this bill in our legislative agenda.

I want to reiterate why it is so important that we have this at the state level beyond the important protections for domestic workers, like minimum wage, rest breaks, protection from retaliation, which we did with the city.
Many people told us, they needed workers compensation, unemployment insurance, Healthcare, retirement assistance.
These are things very hard to do at the city level, so we talk about local control.
You would never really want a city based worker's COMP system, or insurance pool, right?

Those benefit from a much larger, statewide approach, so as it relates to sick leave, and worker's COMP, and unemployment insurance, and Healthcare for these workers, we really did have to defer those priorities to a State- level conversation, so I am very hopeful this will continue to get legs this session because this is the missing element to really fulfilling the request of many domestic workers who worked hand in glove with us, and the business community, who came forward and supported having more protections for domestic workers.

When I the business community, Seattle Nanny network, and other organizations that work directly with domestic workers because they say this is many times a gray market because they can't bring folks out of the fold and people want better standards for these workers, the people will stop undercutting legitimate businesses.
We appreciate folks who worked with us last year, but to fulfill what those workers were asking for, a statewide solution was really needed.
Thank you for including that.
I wanted to talk about how that fit that the city level, and where we couldn't do everything we wanted to do.
The state can really step in and help here.
Thank you, Councilmember Mosqueda.
Onto Quinn Majeski on auto enforcement legislation.
We did have a positive week last week on the automated enforcement of blocking transit lanes.
On Tuesday, there was a hearing in the Senate.
Thank you to Councilmember Strauss for coming down to testify on that.
We also had chief Scoggins from the Seattle fire Department and captain O'Donnell from SPD.
They put together a wonderful panel, and we were joined by a number of Stakeholders, transportation choices coalition, and others.
Overall, a very positive hearing.
The number of legislators have commented that some of their concerns about the legislation have been assuaged, so that was good.
And then on Thursday, the House version passed out of the house, 56-40.
We are hearing that the House version, since it has passed, is going to be that vehicle.
We so expect that Senate action will resume after that hearing in a couple of weeks, once House of origin cutoffs have passed.
And then one other piece of legislation to flag that was just introduced after last week's Council briefing.
Senator Lee's introduced car tabs.

It would transition from the current 1996, evaluation scheduled to the 2006 schedule, and sound transit has stated, publicly, this would reduce their expected revenue by $1 billion, if they bonded to address the short-term implications of losing that revenue.
The overall cost over there, the capital improvement program, would be about $2.93 billion.
The legislation also addresses a portion of 976, specifically 976 repealed sound transit's 1.1% motor vehicle excise tax.
And dropped that to the .3% rate.
This would restore the .1%.
It would require a two thirds vote of the Legislature.
It's an amending initiative that passed within two years.

It does seem that the Senate Republicans are not supportive, and so it's unclear, at this point, if it will have the momentum to gain a two thirds vote, but we are, nonetheless, monitoring it closely given the potential impacts to sound transit, and Light-Rail expansion within the city.
You?
When the House bill comes down to the Senate, I would be happy to come down and testify again.
Thank you so much.
I know sometimes, scheduling occurs at the last minute because the pace is fast in Olympia.
Feel free to keep my office updated.
Much appreciated.
I have one last question.
This goes back to the low carbon fuel standard boat, 52- 44.
I wonder, so that member implies to me that some Democrats in the legislation voted against it.

I wonder if--well, first off, how many Democrats crossed the line, and if any Republicans voted for it, and if there was a geographic kind of break down of where the Democrats that didn't support it represent, and what lessons that might indicate for the chances in the Senate.
Sure.

The current makeup of the House of Representatives is 57-40, which means five Democrats switched over, and voted no with the majority of Republicans, or I should say the unanimous backing for Republicans.
I don't know the geographic distribution.
I believe they represent more rural areas, but I can find those who voted that way, and provide that report to you.
Thank you.
Excellent.
Any additional questions or comments for our legislative team?
Okay.
Closing comments?
We know you are headed down there today.
Thank you again for hearing us out on these various bills.
I think Councilmember Lewis's point is well received.
Thank you for continuing to keep us updated because the slightest word change or the audition of one word can change our position dramatically.
We appreciate you continuing to keep us engaged, and Inc.
You for all of your work down there.
I know it's a Fast-Paced work session.
Good to see all of you again.
We will see you next week.
Okay, we are five minutes ahead of schedule.
Let's go ahead and continue on with a preview of today's Council with an update from all of you.
The preview of today's Council is that we have a few items on the agenda.
Resolution reaffirming Seattle as a welcoming city.
Thank you, Councilmember Pedersen.
The sustainable community, prohibiting Evictions for tendencies preventing Evictions during the winter months.
And five appointments to the Seattle fire code advisory board.

Also, I just want to recognize that our first financing and housing authority Committee is this Thursday, February 6. we have an appointment of the city employees retirement system board of administrations, and also, a discussion about the employee transit, and benefits district.
We may also have an update on the future of work.
More information coming, about that.
Lastly, I want to thank folks who really did help our office out.
I mentioned our incredible team, who, over the last three and half months have really held down the Fort.
I want to thank each of you, and your offices, for working with our team.
The communications team, the clerk's team, central staff.
Thank you to folks in the executive who continue to work with our office, as well.
It was an amazing time to be with my newborn, and I was in communication with her dad.
This is her first day out there just the two of them together.
I wish him the best of luck on his Paternity leave, as well.
It was a great opportunity.
I want to thank you for making it possible.
Lastly, I did have a chance with our daughter, Camilla, to go to two rallies last week.

I want to continue to send our notes of solidarity to the workers at 11 my nine Healthcare West, who are continuing to engage in negotiation, and demand that the bargain be met with folks at Swedish, and Providence, and Unfortunately, as many of you know, were turned away when they went back last week.
So, we are sending a message of solidarity today as they wrap up their negotiations, hopefully, and they hear the city, as we stood in solidarity with them downtown last week.
Also, I have a chance to join U.S. 21, who work at the Macy's retail store downtown.
Some of you may know, it's closing its doors downtown.
Unfortunately, the folks who are downtown are getting offered a different severance package than those on the North end on the South end.

Less severance benefits, and less overall compensation, and, you know, recognizing we represent one of the most expensive places to live in the state, and the hardest places to find housing, hoping that those negotiations continue, and ended up in a good place.
Really hoping that our friends step up, and show what it means.
We know businesses close their doors.
People open their doors off and on, hoping this is a good example for other retail businesses when transition happens.
So, thank you to those unions, workers, and the small businesses who stood with those workers, as well.
I look forward to working with all of you.
That's my update.
Councilmember Sawant.
Thank you, president Mosqueda.
Welcome back.
Thank you.
I wanted to echo your point about the Healthcare workers at 1199, who are conducting a valiant struggle.
It's incredible how much community support there was for them.
In some cases, they actually had 1000 people estimated at one Pickett.
It was really incredible.
I want to thank all of my staff, and members of the Socialist alternative, who were there, at the picket lines, and thank you for sharing the Macy's worker concerns, as well.
There is one item on today's city council agenda from the Sustainability and Renter rights committee.
That's the ordinance you mentioned on banning winter Evictions.
The winter Evictions legislation prevents Renters, tenants, from being turnout during the cold, winter months.
The legislation does not prevent all Evictions, but it doesn't stop people who are behind on their rent from being forced onto the streets during the cold and what part of the year.

We saw the study, sponsored by the way man's Commission, losing homes showed predominately Colic overwhelmingly, the people who are unable to pay their rent fall short by very small amounts, and they are overwhelmingly black women let household, and very low income people.
This is clearly in line with every aspect of social justice we might think of as far as housing is concerned.
Last November, the Seattle Renters Commission asked a recommendation to the city Council to put forward this legislation.

It would be the first of its kind in the U.S., although some kinds of protections in the winter months are in place in some other cities and States, but this proposal that was brought forward by the Renter's Commission is modeled after something that has been in existence for seven decades in France, so it will be quite an innovative thing that we would be doing.

My office introduced the first version of that legislation last December, and then on January 23 at the Sustainability and Renter's rights Committee, we had a very engaged discussion on an amended version of the legislation that I put forward in December.
The amended version incorporates a lot of the feedback we heard from tenant rights advocates, and small landlords.
At that meeting, Councilmember Lewis indicated he would like to look into medication funding to possibly prepare an amendment.
Thank you for being in touch with Jonathan Rosenblum from my office about that.
I understand, it's ready for today, but I will let you say more about that.

There were also questions raised about how the just cause Evictions ordinance, and therefore this winter Evictions ban ordinance because it's sort of modeled after the just cause, would impact people on fixed term leases.
The question has now been answered for all Council offices.
In short, there's a loophole at the end of fixed term leases.
There is a loophole in the just cause Eviction ordinance.
We are aware of it.

My office has been in conversations with the city attorney's office for more than a couple of years now, wanting to close this loophole, but they've had some concerns, so we have deferred to that, but I think it is now time to address that.

But that's something that we can do separately from a just cause, to sort of bring forward a full-fledged just cause Eviction notice that we do plan to do from my office, but that would be a separate ordinance.
Other than that, all Renters are covered by just cause, and therefore all Renters would be covered by this bill, as well because it's modeled after just cause.
There's also a question about what medication funding exists for tenants and landlords.

My personal view is that landlords should not have medication funding because, really, if you provide medication funding to the landlord, and the tenant, then the landlord gets paid and the tenant gets to maintain the housing, so just being motivated from the tenants, the landlords.

However, that question has also been answered, as far as I understand from Washington community action network, Emailing the Council last week with information about the state medication funds already in existence for landlords, and about the mitigation funds for tenants, particularly through the Home-Based program.
I would support increased funding for the Home-Based program, and also, looking for ways to help more tenants know this is an option.
I think this is a significant barrier to tenants who don't know.
When they find out, it's too late and Eviction proceedings are already underway.

That's one place for the Council can have a lot of impact with the Department, really doing much better outreach for the tenants, letting them know that this exists . As for my office, at this point, we have now seen, and addressed every question, an amendment that has been brought forward, to our knowledge.

And because Councilmember Lewis was working on an amendment, we delayed the bill, so it is now on today's city council agenda, rather than last week is puff, but I understand some Councilmembers would still like more time, and I appreciate that, so I have agreed to support holding the bill for another week through February, but I would urge all Councilmembers who have any further concerns aside from the ones that have been addressed or have ideas for amendments, if you could please reach out to my office as soon as possible, so we can get this underway.
